Study The oxide of graphene touches the blood: in vivo interactions of materials 2D bio - crowns The oxide of graphene is the hot topic in biomedical and pharmaceutical research of the current decade. However, its complex interactions with human blood components complicates the transition from the promising results in vitro to clinical environments. Although the oxide of graphene is made with the same atoms as our organs, tissues and cells, its bidimensional nature causes unique interactions with blood proteins and biological membranes and can lead to serious effects such as thrombogenicity and activation of immune cells. In this review, we will describe the journey of the oxide of graphene after injection into the blood stream, from the initial interactions with plasma proteins to the formation of the "biomolecular crown " and the biodistribution of the cells. We will consider the link between the chemical properties of the oxide of graphene (and its functionalised / reduced derivatives ), the binding to proteins and the in vivo response. We will also summarize the data on biodistribution and toxicity in view of the knowledge processes.

The TDS reader measures the conductivity of the water. Measure in PPM (Parts Per Million ). Pure water H2O or distilled water, does not lead electricity, so if a TDS reader is immersed in a fully distilled water the result will be “0” or a very low number in case there are traces of minerals in the water.
